thread.title: Media file complaint about access during Charles Tan trial
thread.title_full: Media file complaint about access during Charles Tan trial

author: democratandchronicle.com
title: Media file complaint about access during Charles Tan trial
text:
Rochester media filed a formal complaint Friday with a judicial oversight commission about courtroom access issues that arose during the trial of Charles Tan. During the trial of Tan, accused of murdering his father, the jury visited the Tan home in Pittsford where the February killing occurred. County Court Judge James Piampiano, who oversaw the trial, denied media requests to accompany the jury into the house.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Complete coverage: Charles Tan murder trial
The complaint from the Democrat and Chronicle and WHAM-TV (Channel 13) to the state Commission on Judicial Conduct alleges that Piampiano ignored longstanding laws about media access when he denied the media requests to visit the home with the jury. Piampiano did allow the media to be 300 feet from the home.
Also, the complaint states, Piampiano, when denying the request, did not allow the media time to contact an attorney to make an argument for access.
The complaint notes that both WHAM-TV and the Democrat and Chronicle "reached out to Judge Piampiano before the jurors traveled to the Tan household" to discuss media accommodations. Neither received a formal response.
Also, the complaint notes, a representative of the Office of Court Administration, the state agency that oversees the court, told WHAM-TV that the crime scene "should be viewed as a 'court exhibit''' and access granted. The OCA official noted that Piampiano could designate a "pool reporter," a single reporter who would go into the home and report observations to the rest of the media. WHAM-TV proposed this alternative in emails to Piampiano the morning of the jury visit to the home.
ROCHESTER DEMOCRAT AND CHRONICLE
Tan won't testify; closing arguments Tuesday
Piampiano said Friday that he could not comment on issues surrounding the case, which ended in a mistrial Oct. 8 after a jury did not reach a verdict over eight days of deliberations.
VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Charlie Tan walks out of court after mistrial | 02:43 Attorneys and jurors in the Charles Tan murder case comment on the mistrial. Video by Jamie Germano
1 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Piampiano on dismissing the jury | 01:31 Judge Piampiano say he doesn't regret dismissing the jury during an interview with columnist David Andreatta. Carlos Ortiz/ staff photographer
2 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Data Visualization: Tan trial by the numbers | 00:50 A look at some of the numbers behind the Charles Tan murder trial. Angie Nassar/Gary Craig/Jon Hand, David Andreatta
3 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Tan jurors: 'We did the best we could with what we were given' | 01:50 Three jurors in the Charles Tan case speak out after a mistrial was declared on Oct. 8. Video by Jamie Germano
4 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Piampiano on the accomplice charge | 01:10 Judge James Piampiano on the accomplice charge. Carlos Ortiz/ staff photographer
5 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Tan trial juror: We were shocked when judge stopped us | 01:04 Juror Tracy Carpenter-Adams talks about how they went over the evidence and thought some key questions weren't answered during the trial of Charles Tan. Video by Tina MacIntyre-Yee
6 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Attorneys: Charles Tan mistrial became 'inevitable,' jury was 'stuck' | 02:02 Attorneys on both sides, ADA William Gargan and defense lawyer Brian DeCarolis, discuss the mistrial in the Charles Tan murder case. Video by Jamie Germano
7 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Video: The moment Charles Tan learned he remains a free man | 01:33 A hung jury has been unable to reach a verdict in the murder trial of Charles Tan, prompting a judge to bring an end to the proceedings. Angie Nassar/Max Schulte
8 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Charles Tan will not testify in trial over dad's killing | 01:08 Charles Tan is on trial for the shooting death of his father, Liang "Jim" Tan.
9 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Charles Tan back in court | 01:10 The Pittsford teen is accused of killing his father in February. Jeff DiVeronica/ staff photographer
10 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Charles Tan arraigned, pleads not guilty | 01:43 Charles Tan's defense attorney, James Nobles, prosecutor William Gargan, and Tan's former soccer coach, Kevin McPherson, react after his arraignment. Video by Lauren Petracca
11 of 12 VIDEOS: THE CHARLES TAN MURDER CASE Attorney: Evidence of abusive relationship in Tan household | 01:33 James Nobles speaks about the Pittsford shooting, which resulted in the death of a 49-year-old man and charges against his 19-year-old son. Video by Max Schulte
12 of 12 Last Video Next Video Charlie Tan walks out of court after mistrial Piampiano on dismissing the jury Data Visualization: Tan trial by the numbers Tan jurors: 'We did the best we could with what we were given' Piampiano on the accomplice charge Tan trial juror: We were shocked when judge stopped us Attorneys: Charles Tan mistrial became 'inevitable,' jury was 'stuck' Video: The moment Charles Tan learned he remains a free man Charles Tan will not testify in trial over dad's killing Charles Tan back in court Charles Tan arraigned, pleads not guilty Attorney: Evidence of abusive relationship in Tan household The Commission on Judicial Conduct can issue admonitions that a judge erred in his or her actions and can recommend removal from the bench. In their complaint, the media organizations note that they did not seek serious punishment for what they perceived as Piampiano's legally wrong decision to block the media from the Tan home.
“We think Judge Piampiano erred in not fully hearing the concerns of the media covering the Tan trial when they were raised," said Democrat and Chronicle news director Dick Moss. "We are not interested in the judge’s punishment as much as we are in reminding other judges of the proper procedures going forward.”
Matt Malyn, the WHAM-TV news director, said, "13WHAM News along with our media colleagues in Rochester adamantly believe in the public’s right to total transparency in the judicial process. This did not happen in the Charlie Tan case and can’t be allowed to continue in the future.
"When the public is deprived of that transparency it’s impossible to have total trust in the process," he said.
Joining in the complaint with WHAM-TV and the Democrat and Chronicle were WROC (Channel 8), WHEC (Channel 10), and Time Warner Cable News.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com
